slides.title: Using Components
slides.content:
# Imports üì¶

Components are standard variables.

To use a component, import it and use it as a tag (uppercase).

```html
<script>
import Nested from './Nested.svelte';
</script>

<Nested />
```

slides.title: Event Dispatching
Event Forwarding
slides.content:
# Forwarding üì®

Unlike DOM events, custom events don't bubble.

To pass an event through a component, just add `on:eventname` without a handler.

```html
<!-- Inner.svelte -->
<button on:click>Click me</button>
```
Now `Inner` emits a `click` event when the button is pressed.

slides.title: Context API
slides.content:
# Context üì°

For deep data passing without prop drilling.

- `setContext(key, value)`
- `getContext(key)`

Must be called during component initialization.

```javascript
import { getContext } from 'svelte';
const theme = getContext('theme');
```

slides.title: Module Context
slides.content:
# <script context="module"> üåè

Run code once per *module* (not per instance).

Useful for sharing data between all instances of a component or exporting constants.

```html
<script context="module">
  export function alertUser() { alert('Hi') }
</script>
```

slides.title: Special Elements
slides.content:
# <svelte:self> ü™û

For recursive components (e.g., a Folder tree).

Use `<svelte:self>` to include the component inside itself.

Also `<svelte:component this={selectedComp} />` for dynamic components.

# Recap: Components üéì

Modular UI.

- **Props:** `export let name`.
- **Slots:** `<slot>`.
- **Events:** `dispatch('name')`.
- **Forwarding:** `on:click` (no handler).
- **Context:** Use for deep data.
